of my enemies; you anoint my head with oil;
and my cup runs over.

1683.95.text:
Surely goodness and mercy shall follow me
all the days of my life; and I will dwell

1688.58.text: in the house of the Lord forever."

1692.85.text:
Please notice in verse 5 we have a change
of metaphor, a change of picture.

1697.91.text:
We're not dealing with sheep and a shepherd
any longer.

1700.52.text:
We're now inside the tent being the guest
to someone who is being the host and lavishly

1708.68.text:
Unless you're prepared to think of little
sheep sitting around a little table drinking

1711.43.text:
coffee, which is a ridiculous thought, understand
that the metaphor has changed.

1717.00.text:
Now we're dealing with God, not as a shepherd,
but God as a host who lavishes upon us what

1723.93.text:
the Middle East is so famous for; and that
is, hospitality.

1729.68.text:
One time I was in the city of Nazareth where
Jesus grew up.

1735.33.text: I was with a few guys from our church.

1737.43.text: We were doing a little film of the area.

1741.84.text: And this guy comes out of the house.

1748.13.text: He was a Palestinian Arab living in Nazareth.

1750.37.text: He invited us into his home.

1751.48.text:
He gave us coffee, gave us tea, wanted to
give us food, which he did.

1756.26.text:
Then asked us to stay through the night and
have a huge meal with his family.

1759.73.text:
We were unable to do that, but I just thought,
"Here's a perfect stranger inviting perfect

1765.11.text:
strangers into his house willing to give us
everything he's got."

1771.98.text: That's the picture that is drawn here.

1774.19.text:
In ancient times when you went into somebody's
tent as a visitor, there was a protocol.

1781.05.text:
First of all, they would give you the common
kiss three times: on one cheek, the other

1785.76.text: cheek, and then back to the first cheek.

1789.03.text:
Then the servant would remove your sandals
and wash your feet.

1793.18.text:
Then they would place oil on your face, on
your head, a scented olive oil to refresh

1801.17.text:
Then they would give you a glass of wine with
honey, a very sweet mixture to bring you refreshment.

1807.46.text:
Then they would spread a rug before you and
they would serve you a meal.

1815.91.text: Notice that David says, "my cup runs over."

1819.23.text:
Can't you just picture the host just pouring,
pouring, and the guest going, "No, no.

1824.83.text: He just kind of keeps pouring over and over.

1828.50.text:
Sometimes I play a little joke on my friends,
you know, we're sitting at lunch and I have

1834.45.text: And they say, "Hey, can I have some more water?"

1835.45.text:
And I just sort of keep pouring and keep pouring
and keep pouring till it just overflows onto

1838.69.text: the table and looks like they made a mess.

1840.29.text:
I know, it's an adolescent thing to do, but
what can I say?

1845.36.text:
[laughter] God isn't playing a joke on his
guests.

1850.07.text:
The idea is that "You are just so abundant
in your provision and your love for me, Lord,

1860.40.text:
And then you'll notice it's followed by "Surely

1868.42.text:
That's a declaration of the future based on

1872.60.text:
"Surely goodness and mercy will follow me
all the days of my life."

1878.34.text:
He would say that because that's been the

1881.59.text:
"You have taken care of me and protected me
and directed me and taken care of me all through

1890.03.text:
I am now sure that in the future you're going

1894.62.text:
He's not saying, "I declare by faith that
my life will be painless from now on."

1900.53.text:
After all, he's eating "in the presence of"---his
what?---"enemies."

1909.41.text:
But though his enemies pursue him, what David
is saying is, "I know that goodness and mercy

1915.26.text:
will also chase after me all the days of my
life, because it's always been that way.

1923.12.text:
I'm making a declaration of my future based
upon the past."

1926.54.text: This folks, this is a statement of choice.

1928.30.text: This is a statement of faith.

1931.68.text:
It's-it's---forgive the analogy, but in the

1939.72.text: "It's the choice to be Tigger and not Eeyore."

1950.92.text:
It's not, "my cup runneth over," it's, "my
cup leaketh under."

1955.29.text:
[laughter] But then there are those who say,
"No.

1959.35.text:
I'm making a stand, by faith, to declare based
upon who God is, what he has promised, and

1965.14.text:
where he has taken me: 'Surely goodness and

1970.26.text:
"That's a choice to be like Tigger and not

1974.61.text:
Our trouble is that so often we write our
sorrows in the marble, and we write our mercies

1987.87.text:
Surely goodness and mercy will follow me all

1999.08.text:
There was once a famous actor that was invited
to a social gathering.

2003.83.text:
People were so excited to have this actor
there.

2005.82.text:
He was known for his ability to portray characters
and say lines in a way that was unparalleled.

2015.71.text:
So that night at dinner people were asking
him to recite famous lines of different literary

2023.00.text:
There was a minister who was also at that
dinner.

2024.95.text:
And he said, "I'd like you to recite Psalm
23 for the audience."

2030.58.text:
And the actor said, "I'd love to do that,
under one condition, that after I'm done you

2038.97.text:
So the actor, as you would expect, in typical
eloquence like a thespian would, rising of

2044.92.text:
his voice and the falling of his voice, just
said it perfectly.

2050.75.text:
And afterwards people gave him a cheering
round of applause that lasted for several

2058.02.text:
He was older, his voice was a little rougher,
his eloquence was not perfect, but he recited

2066.06.text:
Psalm 23, and after he did, there was not
a dry eye in the audience.

2076.72.text:
And after dinner they asked the actor, "What
made the difference?"

2079.64.text:
The actor said, "I know the Psalm, he knows
the Shepherd."

2085.44.text:
We all know the Psalm, everybody knows this
Psalm, but do you know the Shepherd?

2093.12.text: Do you know his direction in your life?

2095.11.text: Do you know his protection in your life?

2097.80.text:
Do you feel and experience his provision in
your life?

2100.68.text:
Can you say, "The Lord is my personal shepherd;
I shall not want"?

2107.06.text:
And it could be, could be that you're just
in a little bit of a rut today.

2111.97.text:
Did you know that one of the---one of the
common problems that sheep have is called

2121.77.text: Shepherds will refer to a "cast sheep."

2124.39.text:
This is a sheep who wanders from the fold,
gets out on his own---"All us like sheep have

2130.69.text:
gone astray"---and wants to just sort of lie
down in a comfortable position, in a little

2136.88.text:
depression in the ground, and just sorts of
lies there, kicks back.

2141.30.text:
And what happens is the sheep turns over just
a little too much and its legs are kind of

2147.95.text:
sticking out, and then tries to shift and
get out of it, its legs sticking up like this.

2153.96.text:
And the sheep cannot for the life of it get
back on its feet.

2158.70.text:
Gases build up inside the abdomen cutting
off the circulation, and the sheep will die

2165.49.text:
unless the shepherd finds it and restores
it.

2168.37.text:
Verse 3, "He restores my soul," means brings
me back.

2174.07.text: Maybe you sort of feel like a cast sheep.

2176.46.text:
You just want to get in a little comfortable
zone and now your legs are sticking straight

2181.95.text:
[laughter] You've wandered just a little too
far, and you need God's goodness and mercy

2188.21.text:
now, let alone following you all the days
of your life.

2192.93.text:
Then you make that decision, like David, to
say, "The Lord is my shepherd.

2197.78.text: I'm coming back to his care, back to his fold."

2200.72.text:
Because here's the catch: all the things about
God as a shepherd will never be true unless

2207.62.text: you let him be the shepherd of your life.

2211.71.text:
You have to come into his fold by an act of
your own will in cooperating with his call.

2219.83.text:
Father, we want to close this message today,
this little devotional, meditation upon this

2228.02.text:
Psalm by acknowledging that not only are you
the shepherd, you are not only the Good Shepherd,

2236.58.text:
the Great Shepherd of the sheep, as it's called
in Scripture, but that you are our shepherd.

2243.51.text:
You're my shepherd, and because of that I
really have no needs.

2254.73.text:
You look over the wool and you pick out the
parasites and you make sure we're standing

2260.81.text:
And even though it's dark and we can't see
where we're going and it's painful, you're

2266.80.text:
really bringing us to a place of refreshment,
a place of growth, and a place of understanding

2274.21.text:
and trust in the goodness of your motivation
behind all that you allow us to go through.

2283.00.text:
And even when we feel attacked by the enemy,
we realize, Lord that the enemy can only go

2290.25.text:
And you've given us all the tools to resist
the devil, so that he will flee from us.

2295.22.text:
So, Lord, I pray that we would take comfort
in seeing your staff for directing, and then

2303.32.text:
looking up and seeing your rod, the club,
for protecting.

2308.56.text:
And so, Father, finally, as a declaration
we say that surely goodness and mercy will

2319.06.text:
indeed follow, pursue, chase after us all
the days of our lives, when one day passing

2327.80.text:
through the valley we will wake up in the
light and dwell in the house of the Lord forever,

2341.15.text:
